story: NewsHero boyfriend, , loses leg after pushing girlfriend away from out-of-control carEd Bowen and his partner Nicola Boraston were walking home in Bristol when a car reversed at speed towards them and swerved off the roadShareByTristan Cork:,  NOV NewsEd Bowen, , has been hailed a hero after he pushed Nicola Boraston out of the way of an out-of-control car "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA brave boyfriend has been hailed a hero after he pushed his girlfriend out of the way of an out-of-control car - and suffered terrible injuries when it hit him instead. Ed Bowen, , had to be resuscitated in the ambulance rushing him to hospital, and now faces a very dferent le after his left leg was amputated just below the hip. But now, three weeks after the crash which nearly killed him and changed the lives of he and his partner Nicola Boraston, the couple have been overwhelmed by an outpouring of support from family, friends and strangers in Bristol and beyond. A GoFundMe page set up to help Ed and his family when he is eventually discharged from hospital has already smashed its initial target three times over, and his friends say there will be huge financial and emotional implications for the rest of their lives from the shocking events in Bristol three weeks ago. Bristol Live reports that Ed and Nic were walking home at around .am on October , when they were passed by a car being driven up the hill ahead of them. The car then began to reverse at speed towards them and swerved off the road.  Ed, from Bristol said he leapt into the path of the car to push Nic out of the way. She suffered only minor injuries, but the back of the car pinned Ed to a retaining wall of a garden, crushing his left leg and pelvis, before moving forward and allowing the wall to collapse on top of him. The -year-old suffered such terrible injuries that he medically died in the ambulance rushing him to hospital and had to be resuscitated by paramedics. He underwent  hours of surgery, and spent two weeks in intensive care at Southmead Hospital. Surgeons were unable to save his left leg, and had to amputate it just below the hip. He now faces months of recovery in hospital from his shattered pelvis and years of rehabilitation. “I remember the car hitting me, but I don’t really remember anything too much after that,” he said. “I have spent most of my working le in care work so it feels weird and a challenge to switch to being cared for now.” Police arrested the driver, a man aged  who has not been named, at the scene and later released him on bail.

The Home Office confirmed today that it has allocated the money to allow Scotland Yard to continue its investigation until March. Madeleine was three when she vanished while on holiday with her parents in Praia da Luz, Portugal, in May . Scotland Yard launched its own investigation, Operation Grange, into her disappearance in , after a Portuguese inquiry failed to make any headway. Force bosses have been applying for funding from the Home Office every six months to continue the inquiry, that has cost about pound. million so far.  Madeleines parents, Kate and Gerry McCann, have always pledged never to give up the search for their daughter. A Home Office spokesman said: We have confirmed that Special Grant funding of pound, will be provided to the politan Police Service for the six-month period to  March . A former counter-terror detective previously said it is vitally important to keep searching for the girl over  years later. Speaking on Good Morning Britain , David Videcette said Met Police must be given more funding to discover what happened to Maddie. He said: If she had been abducted, then we need to catch whoever did that because it will happen again.  However much money we spend on this case, well save on the next casewe catch that person and thats where we need to look at. The sum that has already been spent on the McCann investigation has sparked public debate, with some critics claiming there are many other missing children who havent been given the same resources.  Also on GMB was founding member of Scotland Yards undercover unit, Peter Bleksley who argued it was dficult to justy spending more when police appear to be no closer to finding Maddie. He said: There has to be a point where they say you know what we have to put this file in the too dficult tray because quite frankly we are unable to solve it. How much more money has to be ploughed into this, are there still live investigate threads that are going to potentially lead to some kind of resolution  years on  At some stage, this has to stop.  Meanwhile, Videcette insisted money shouldnt be an issue, adding: Good investigations take time. Madeleine - daughter of doctors Kate and Gerry McCann - was nearly four when she went missing from their holiday apartment in Praia da Lua.  The couple were dining in the holiday complexs restaurant while Maddie and her siblings were sleeping in the nearby apartment. At pm they realised she was gone, sparking a frantic hunt of the resort and surrounding area.  There have been many reported sightings of the girl - who would now be  - around the world over the years. However there is no concrete evidence to suggest her location orshes still alive.

title: official prince charles birthday photos
story: NewsOfficial Prince Charles birthday photos show royal family looking relaxed and happyMeghan Markle and Kate were pictured with Prince William, Harry and their family in touching photos taken for the milestone birthdayShareCommentsByRachael Bletchly:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsGone are the stuffy indoor Royal portraits - this time, the family have taken a fresh approach to their family photo "Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWhen Gramps is celebrating the big -O, every loving family wants to gather for a souvenir snap. Buthe’s also in the Royal Family, that usually means a row of chairs in a Buckingham Palace drawing room and glum kids rigid with boredom. So the official photos marking the Prince of Wales’ th birthday are truly a breath of fresh air. They capture the smiling face of a modern monarchy, and the loving bond between Charles and his close-knit clan. The heir to the throne sits on a bench beaming, surrounded by his family.  And, while that bench is probably hand-carved oak and the Clarence House lawn freshly mown by a gardener, the Wales-Cornwall-Cambridge-Sussexes really look like a NORMAL happy family. One touching shot shows them collapsing in giggles at something happening behind the camera. Gangly Prince George, five, who is perched on his Grandpapa’s knee, roars with laughter while Camilla cuddles smiling Princess Charlotte, three, pointing out the incident.  Harry, with his arm round his we’s waist, sees it too and pregnant Meghan doubles over laughing. Sensible William keeps his eye on the photographer, probably urging the others to get a grip, while smiling Kate bounces a chubby-legged Prince Louis, six months. And while dapper Charles is wearing one of his Savile Row pin-stripes, his sons are informally dressed in open-necked shirts.  They are the picture of a loving and devoted family. This week William and Harry paid a moving tribute to Papa in a TV documentary marking his birthday. And the pair, who grew closer than ever to their father following the tragic death of Princess Diana, said they wanted him to be a big part in their own children’s lives. Camilla, also interviewed for the programme, said: “He’s wonderful with children. He doesn’t mind crawling on the floor for hours with them. We had a picture the other day with Louis pulling on his hair. He loves it. He’s exceptionally good with very small children and babies.”  Charles has clearly mellowed over the past decade and become more relaxed about family photoshoots. Just before his marriage to Camilla in  he took his sons on a stag do ski trip to the posh resort of Klosters. On a photoshoot the Prince was caught on microphone slating the press and BBC reporter Nicholas Witchell.  Grinning through gritted teeth, he told his sons: “I hate doing this. Bloody people. “I can’t bear that man [Witchell]. He’s so awful, he really is. I hate these people.” Urged by a photographer to “look like you know each other” the boys leaned closer.  Charles grumped: “Do I put my arms round you  What do we do ” William replied: “Keep smiling, keep smiling.” Charles wisely followed the advice and in the  years since has learned much more from William and Harry about showing emotion in public.  At  he seems more comfortable in his skin than ever before. And, as these pictures show, the modern monarchy is facing the future with a smile.

story: NewsPrince Louis looks just like dad Wills as he flashes cheeky smile in new photosThe young prince, who is nearly seven months old, looked adorable in the first official photographs of him since his christening in JulyShareCommentsBySophie Evans:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsPrince Louis flashes a cheeky smile in the newly-released photograph "Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailPropped up in his mums arms, Prince Louis flashes a cheeky smile in a new royal photograph to mark his grandads th birthday. The pair have a similar mouth and chubby cheeks - with Louis also sharing the same button nose that his father had as a tot. title: teen faces being school until
story: NewsTeen kicked out of class after getting ears pierced faces being off school until Ellie-Rose Longley-Hall, , was put in isolation after wearing her new gold stud earrings to class at Kingwood Academy in HullShareCommentsByElaine McCahillAlex Grove:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsEllie-Rose Longley-Hall faces being out of Kingswood Academy in Hull for six weeks after being kicked out of class over her stud earrings "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA teenage girl is facing being out of school for six weeks because she got her ears pierced and wore gold studs to class. Ellie-Rose Longley-Hall was put in isolation because of the studs and so her mum Katie Marsham, , decided to take her out of Kingwood Academy in Hull. The -year-old had only got her ears pierced two days before and went into school with a pair of gold studs which had small blue diamonds in them. However, staff at the school said she would have to remove the earrings or be forced to work “in consequences” – a form of isolation where pupils are segregated from their classmates. Disgusted by the decision, Mrs Marsham took Ellie-Rose out of school as she did not think she deserved to be punished because of her earrings, reports Hull Live.  The mum-of-four said: “I brought her home because she can’t be sat in there when she should be studying. I think it’s wrong, especially when it’s her last year of school and she has had a lot going on in her le at the minute. “I think it’s childish and a bit over the top, and I’m not sending her back to school so that she can be segregated from the classroom in consequences.” Ellie-Rose plucked up the courage to have her ears pierced last weekend despite having a “fear of needles”. However, her mum said she cannot take them out for another six weeks as they may become infected meaning she may notto school until next year.  Mrs Marsham says her daughter is already “stressed out” by the prospect of facing such a y time out of school and she is worried the Year  pupil could now fail her GCSEs. She said: “Ellie-Rose has got exams coming up and she is supposed to have one on Friday. She is going to fail themshe has to stay out of school that long and I don’t want that to happen because she has been working really hard. “She has just had two weeks off school with illness and that has affected her schoolwork. I don’t want this to affect her either but they’ve said she can’t go back to school until she changes them.” It comes after the school told at least three boys to get their hair cut or be put in isolation.  Leroy and TJ Wilson were told their hairdos did not meet unorm policy with Bradley Thompson’s mum also told by the school to sort out his hair or find another school. Leroy and TJ’s mother, Terri Lea Wilson, branded the school’s decision to put them “in consequences” as “cruel and “ridiculous.” Kingswood Academy says it expects the highest standards from its pupils when it comes to school unorms. Anyone who fails to meet these expectations is placed in isolationthey do not recty the issue. A spokesman for the academy said: We at the academy have the highest of expectations regarding unorm - including jewellery - which have been in place for the last three years.  “These expectations are made very clear in the unorm policy which is shared with parents and students annually, and is also displayed on the academy website. “Any student who fails to meet the standard initially has an opportunity to recty the issue,not they are placed in isolation. “In February , Kingswood Academy was judged to be Good in all categories and Ofsted commented specically on how proud students were of their school and their unorm, which they wear with pride.

title: unborn baby survives crossbow bolt
story: NewsUnborn baby survives crossbow bolt that killed pregnant mum as she did washingThe baby boy, named Ibrahim, was delivered by emergency caesarean after his mother, Sana Muhammad, , was shot by an intruderShareByTom PettorOliver Milne:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsThe baby boy, named Ibrahim, was delivered by emergency caesarean"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA baby boy who survived in the womb after a crossbow bolt killed his mother missed is in hospital after being delivered by emergency caesarean. The boy’s mum, Sana Muhammad, , who was eight months pregnant, was shot by an intruder at her home in front of her terried husband and five children at .am on Monday. The crossbow bolt is reported to have missed the baby, reportedly named Ibrahim, by inches. Husband Imtiaz Muhammad, , said Sana was shot as she tried to flee after he had found her alleged killer hiding in their garden shed.  Mr Muhammad, the director of a building company, said: “I went to put a cardboard box in the shed. He was there with the crossbow loaded. “He stared at me, he was going to shoot so I ran into the house. My we was doing the washing-up, I was shouting, ‘Run, run, run’. “He shot her. I can’t help thinking she took my arrow. Maybe it should have hit me. The kids were all there, it was horric.”  Police last night said a man arrested over the attack in Ilford, East London, was known to Mrs Muhammad. The spokesman confirmed the baby was “stable” but still in hospital. Sana was said to have been shot as she ran up the stairs, the bolt passing through her thigh into her stomach.  A neighbour said: “Imtiaz came out the house screaming for help – he was banging on doors. We called the police and they were there quick. The kids were all there and they were crying for help. It was .am, so the devil must have been there in the night, lying in wait.” The witness said the alleged killer had surrendered to police.  Tributes were paid to Sana, originally from Mauritius, who was pronounced dead at am on Monday. Friends said she had three children, aged ,  and , with her first husband, and two daughters, aged five and two, with South African Imtiaz.

title: womans lips looked like raw
story: NewsWomans lips looked like raw meat after baby oil injected instead of fillerKerry Miles claims her lips were left burning and blistered and says it has taken her two years to get them back to normalShareCommentsByCharlotte Nisbet:,  NOV NewsKerry Miles, whose idol is Barbie, pictured now "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA woman claims her lips looked like raw meat after baby oil was allegedly injected into them instead of filler. Kerry Miles, , says her lips doubled in size after the alleged botched job. She says just an hour after the half-an-hour procedure, her lips were burning and blistered. Kerry later decided to have the lip filler drained and claims a doctor told her the filler appeared to have been mixed with another substance like baby oil. It has since taken Kerry two years to get her lips back to normal after the ordeal, she says. But despite her devastation and pain, the mum-of-one from Chelmsford, Essex, says she isnt deterred from having her lips done.After finding a clinic online that she thought was reputable, Kerry had booked her treatment and paid pound for the lip filler. Kerry, a model and promoter, said: I picked a reputable clinic but I had doubts as soon as I turned up. The house was rundown and looked grubby, there was even a dog running around. It didnt look very hygienic but I wanted my lips done and she had good reviews. She was mixing the filler in front of me and Im certain she was using some sort of household oil.  She added: Ive never had a reaction to filler before but this was horric. I couldnt go outdoors for days as the pain was so bad and I looked awful. I phoned her to complain but she told me I wasnt drinking enough water and I should massage my lips to make them the right shape. When I had the filler drained by a doctor I was told that the filler had been mixed with baby oil, I was so shocked. It has taken years to get them back to normal but thankfully I am now happy with them.  Kerry went on to have more filler to try and disguise her lumpy lips but it took years to dissolve. She added: It wouldnt dissolve like normal filler as it was a mixture of substances. I should never have trusted her with my face. I have also had Botox, vampire facials and a nose job to try and perfect my face. The experience hasnt put me off having my lips done as I still get them done now. Im just extremely careful about who I chose now after everything I went through a few years ago.  Kerrys idol is Barbie and she has spent thousands on procedures to try and improve her looks. She added: I enjoy improving my body and keeping my face looking youthful. I wouldnt warn people not to have lip fillers but I would say do your research. I was left feeling so embarrassed after my ordeal and now Im always over cautious.  Kerry says she conducts background checks on everyone she books for her fillers now. I should have trusted my instincts when the house I arrived at wasnt clean but I learnt the hard way, she said.I hope others can learn from my mistakes.

title: el chapo trial joaquin guzman
story: NewsEl Chapo trial: Guzman is scapegoat for REAL cartel boss who bribed presidentEl Chapos lawyer told jurors the accused drug lord "controlled nothing" and the real leader of Mexicos Sinaloa Cartel is Ismael "El Mayo" ZambadaShareByBrendan PiersonDanya BazaraaNews ReporterNatalie Evans:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news world-news video watch-el-chapos-we-arrives-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAccused Mexican drug lord Joaquin El Chapo Guzman is a scapegoat for the real leader of Mexicos Sinaloa Cartel, his lawyer claims. The trial of El Chapo began with lawyers opening statements in a federal court in Brooklyn late on Tuesday, amid intense public attention and extraordinary security measures. The days hearing was delayed due to an anxious and upset juror who brought a doctors note to court to help get taken off the case. Guzmans attorney Jeffrey Lichtman told the court his client was merely a scapegoat for the real drug cartel leader, Ismael El Mayo Zambada.  Hes blamed for being the leader while the real leaders are living freely and openly in Mexico, attorney Jeffrey Lichtman said. In truth he controlled nothing. Mayo Zambada did. Zambada, who is still at large, had bribed Mexican President Enrique Pena Nieto, said Lichtman. Pena Nietos spokesman said of the accusation: That is .  Guzman, who dramatically escaped from Mexican maximum security prisons twice, has been kept in solitary confinement in Manhattan and transported to court in Brooklyn in a heavily guarded motorcade. Assistant U.S. Attorney Adam Fels laid out the U.S. governments case, describing how prosecutors would prove that Guzman rose from a low-level marijuana trafficker in the s to lead the powerful Sinaloa Cartel, leaving a trail of violence in his wake.  Federal prosecutors say that Guzman, , directed massive shipments of heroin, cocaine, marijuana and methamphetamine bound for the United States. He faces  criminal counts and a potential le sentenceconvicted, and the trial could last up to four months. As well as smuggling drugs to the United States, the Sinaloa Cartel has played a major role in narco violence between rival gangs that has torn areas of Mexico apart. His nickname El Chapo, a reference to his five foot, six inchheight, is often translated in English as shorty. The US Government said they plan to tell El Chapo’s story - part history, part biographical - during the -year-old’s trial in New York.  As well as smuggling drugs to the United States, the Sinaloa Cartel has played a major role in narco violence between rival gangs that has torn areas of Mexico apart and defied successive governments. More than , people have been killed - many in cartel feuds - since the Mexican government sent troops in to take on the drug gangs in . Guzmans lawyers have signaled that they intend to downplay their clients role in the cartel and argue that the prosecutors witnesses are motivated by self interest and not believable.  The security around El Chapo is so strict that US District Judge Brian Cogan, who is presiding over the case, last week denied a motion by Guzman asking to hug his we before the trial. According to court filings, witnesses will include former Sinaloa Cartel members and others involved in the drug trade who are now cooperating with the U.S. government. None have been publicly named, and some may testy under aliases.  The jurors will remain anonymous and be escorted to and from court by armed US marshals. Prosecutors have said the security is necessary because of Guzmans history of intimidating and even ordering murders of potential witnesses. But Guzmans lawyers have called those claims unfounded.  Guzman was one of worlds most wanted fugitives until he was captured in January  in Sinaloa. He was extradited to the US a year later. In , Forbes Magazine put him on its list of the worlds richest people, with an estimated  billion fortune but investigators say it is impossible to know exactly how much he was worth.

title: woman who can remember everything
story: NewsWoman who can remember EVERYTHING since  days old - including tastes and smellsEXCLUSIVE: Rebecca Sharrock, , has Highly Superior Autobiographical Memory and can remember everything from her first birthday to her school daysShareCommentsByElaine McCahill:,  NOV NewsRebecca Sharrock was born with Highly Superior Autobiographical Memory and can remember everything in her le since she was  days old "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMost people would love to remember everything - from how they felt at the happiest moments of their lives to the answers to exam questions.But for Rebecca Sharrock, never being able to forget is both a blessing and a curse. The -year-old was born with an extremely rare neurological condition that means she can remember nearly everything that’s ever happened to her in her le. Her first memory is of having her picture taken at  days old. And she can recall the minute details of her first birthday party - from the itchy satin dress she wore to the Minnie Mouse teddy that terried her. While some memories are more vivid than others, Rebecca can always remember the emotions she felt - as well as the tastes and smells she encountered. Her mind is filled with endless flashbacks - from magical Christmases as a child to more hurtful memories of her being bullied at school. The young woman, from Brisbane, Australia, told : “My memories are all in sequence, they come in a chronological order by days and times. “My earliest memory is of having my picture taken at  days old. “I saw a picture of that photo when I was  but I always remembered it and would speak to my mum about it in my early childhood. She was shocked that I could remember and when I saw the photo, it was dated the rd of December  when I was  days old. “It never occurred to me that it wasn’t normal to remember things like that.  Rebecca is one of around only  people in the world who have Highly Superior Autobiographical Memory , or a super memory.While her happy memories are wonderful, she admits it’s tough being able to recall every detail of her le - from what clothes she was wearing to exactly how she felt when something bad or embarrassing happened to her on a certain day. Her over-active mind also causes her to suffer from headaches and insomnia - but she has learned to quieten her mind by reading the Harry Potter novels. She now knows all the books by heart and recites them in her mind to calm her down and help her fall asleep. “The memories make it dficult to get to sleep when it’s dark and silent because I just get distracted, she told us. It happens all through the day but when I’m trying to sleep I just get random flashbacks and it keeps me awake. That’s why I learned to recite the Harry Potter books. While remembering everything certainly has its perks, Rebecca says her mind often feels “overwhelmed” and cluttered with memories. A particularly negative recollection can often ruin her day. She is currently in therapy and is working on ways to repress particularly painful memories and keep the incessant flashbacks at bay. “There are a few memories from my early childhood that are the absolute worst and I hate reliving those, said Rebecca. I want to get rid of those memories because I was going through a phase of depression when I was  and I don’t like reliving those emotions and feelings again. “When they’re negative, I like to call them intrusive memories. It could be a day I was looking forward to but something could remind me of a negative memory and the negative emotions flood back and it just ruins the whole day for me.  “I’ve been doing therapy for the past few years and my therapist has given me exercises to deal with my memories and they’re used for people suffering from PTSD. “One is called leaves on a stream, I just imagine taking every thought out of my mind and putting it on a leaf and it’s floating away. That just grounds my mind. While some of us still cringe at memories from our embarrassing teenage years, they flood back for Rebecca asits happening right then and there all over again. The intense experience can be incredibly painful and dficult to cope with over and over again. “I dream about my past all the time too, and they’re always about my school days, said the young woman. “I just relive the embarrassment of whenever I did something at school. Emotions come back, physical sensations come back, tastes and smells do as well.  Rebecca also tries to centre her mind by drawing her memories or building her Harry potter Lego set. When a memory comes flooding back, she has to fight the urge to respond in the same way she would have at that time of her le. She explained: “The emotions and the adrenaline I getto whatever age I was at the time of the memory but my conscience and reasoning are like an adult. That makes me feel ashamed and embarrassed and reluctant to be open about them because I know it’s an immature reaction or something silly that I don’t need to worry about. It creates a lot of confusion within me. In recent years, Rebecca has been working with neurologists to help with their research into how memory works. “I’m close to my step-dad’s family and his dad passed away two years ago from Alzheimers, she said. He had it for seven years before he passed away and it was just so sad. If there could be a cure, it would be fantastic. And I’m involved in research that helps find the answers and that means a lot to me. Rebecca has met one other woman who has H-SAM and says it was “incredible” to meet someone who has the same experience. “For the person not to be confused or amazed but just to react asit was a normal thing was amazing, she said.We just couldn’t stop talking the first time we met. It’s so amazing to have a friend who knows exactly what I’m talking about.” While she sometimes wishes she didnt have such an incredible memory, the young woman says the happy memories make it worthwhile. Often, it can feel like time travel. I relive happy memories just as much as negative memories, she said “Those are the moments I’m grateful I have H-SAM, I relive holidays I’ve had, I love going to the Disney and Harry Potter parks. “Most of my happiest memories come from my adulthood and not my childhood.  “Most of my happiest memories come from my trips to Calornia. And although she feels her mind is “constantly cluttered”, she has never felt any other way. “It’s something I’ve grown used to but I knowthis happened to me suddenly I’d be absolutely overwhelmed and I wouldn’t cope with it, said Rebecca. “I get a lot of headaches, I get tired a lot but it’s something I’ve just accepted as part of my le. I’ve just grown used to it. “Whenever I’m getting stressed because my head is just going haywire or I’m having an intrusive memory I do wish I didn’t have it but I like to focus on the positive. She added: “I used to look at it like it as a complete curse but now I’m teaching myself to look at the positive side.I don’t have to keep a diary to remember happy events - they’re just there.And it’s also something interesting to talk about - I love being quirky.

title: dundee photographer reveals secrets behind his most famous pictures
story: A Dundee photographer who snapped everyone from the Queen Mother to Margaret Thatcher during a career spanning six decades has revealed the secrets of his most famous photos.Alex Coupar, , from Coldside, left school in  aged  with dreams of becoming a “snapper”.And during the former Morgan Academy pupil’s time working for DC Thomson he often found himself looking through his lens at the great and the good.One of his regular assignments was photographing royal visits, leading the Queen Mother to recognise him.One moment which sticks out in his memory was being sent to Oban to photograph the Queen in .He said: “There was a huge gale and rain was coming down sideways.“The royal yacht couldn’t even land and the Queen had to step ashore on a pile of fish boxes. She was soaking and wearing a raincoat.“I had to go to Skye afterwards and my suit was soaking wet, so I put my pyjamas on.”He can also recall photographing the Queen Mother standing above Loch Muick in the early s.Alex said: “I was sent to the location at the crack of dawn on a misty morning.“She stopped halfway down the hill and I was kicked out of the Land Rover to ask what she wanted.“She was admiring the view and we did a picture, with the mist around her.“Forty years later, I got a call from the royal archives which wanted to use the pictures.“I went to the shop next day and nearly every newspaper on the stand was carrying the photo.”Alex took pictures for the Evening , The Courier and the People’s Journal until . And during his –year career with DC Thomson, he also met his we, Margaret. The couple have been married for  years.He then ran Spanphoto, his photography studio on South Tay Street, between  and .Alex has seen the Dundee landscape sht and change throughout the decades.He said: “I photographed the huge swimming pool at the Waterfront being built and demolished“I also watched Margaret Thatcher open the Hilton at the Waterfront.”Spanphoto often worked for the city’s Caledon shipyard and also a yard in Burntisland, Fe – both no longer in existence – and Alex is nostalgic about a time when shipbuilding was booming.His own business received a “huge dent in turnover” in the s when Dundee-based supermarket chain, William Low – another of his customers – was bought out by Tesco.Alex said: “It was a big blow for Dundee when it shut.”He also remembers a time when famous faces would come to Dundee Repertory Theatre “in their droves”.He said: “I photographed every production at the Rep for  years at a time when many people would flock to Dundee to see them. I miss it.”After retiring in , he donated his entire collection to Dundee University in the knowledge his work will inspire generations of photographers to come.

title: dundees oldest citizens help teach youngsters about citys incredible stories from days gone by
story: Dundee’s oldest and wisest citizens are being called upon to share their memories with the city’s younger generation.Local charity Food Train Dundee is holding hour-long sessions that pair older locals with kids at St Paul’s RC Academy to record lasting recollections of their past.Over the course of several weeks, the aim is to collate a wide range of memories of le in the city, capturing everything from working le to what people did at the weekends.As well as creating a permanent record of the city as it was for previous generations, the Old Dundee project will also bring together younger and older people.Caitlyn Cooper-McCulloch, befriending intern at Food Train and leader of the project, said the initiative was a radical departure from the Food Train’s usual day-to-day work.The charity, based at The Circle community business centre on Staffa Place, usually assists older people with shopping and linking them with befriending services.Caitlyn said: “I wanted to do some kind of historical project in relation to Dundee and this is what came to mind.“There’s actually a lot of stigma in the two age groups.“A lot of older people look down on kids and then kids look at older people and think they’re boring and that they’re not of any use to them.“We’re hoping that they’ll each discover they have a lot of mutual ground.”Among those taking part in the project is Dundee-born Margaret Hunter, , who has been using the charity’s services for five years.The former nurse said: “I wanted to help the kids and they need to know about things as they once were.“One thing the kids have asked me about is the technology we had growing up – I had to explain to them that all we had was a wireless. Some of the questions they’ve been asking have been really good.”S pupil Zoe Melville, , said the project so far had been “really interesting”.She added: “I like the fact we can ask them all kinds of questions about things like their favourite drinks and sweets.”Although the project started last month, Food Train is still looking for people to get involved in sharing their memories.Caitlyn has extended an open invitation to the city’s older population, with transport available for those who need it.Meetings take place every Monday from .pm-.pm at St Paul’s.The ultimate aim of the project, which will run until the end of this year, is to create a book which can be sold to raise money for Food Train.Caitlyn said: “The idea is that we will create a full book of dferent stories covering everything from jute, Keiller’s, going to the dancing – it’s a social enterprise project to benefit older people in Dundee.”Caitlyn hopes that enough people take an hour out each week to make the project a success.“It would be fantasticthe book happened,” she added.“I’m really passionate about all things ‘old Dundee’.“My own great-gran is  and the stories that she comes away with are incredible.“I just imagine that there are so many other incredible stories that might be lostwe don’t record them – it would be so sadthat happened.”To get involved in the Old Dundee project, call Caitlyn at Food Train Dundee on  .

title: from today dundee plays host to legends of jazz and blues
story: Dundee Jazz Festival is to thrill music fans with more performances than ever before.The festival – featuring performers ranging from international stars to up-and-coming artists – will take place across ious venues in the city from today until Sunday.Organisers say that record sales in  – particularly to a younger audience – have encouraged them to commit to extra events this time round.Producer Agnese Daverio said: “The festival has a new look and feel.“We’re also trying to attract a younger audience – jazz is becoming cool again.“We’ve got jazz, blues, afropunk, swing and acoustics. There’s quite a mix compared with past years.“There is so much iety on offer this year. At a time when the city is undergoing a massive transition, we’re at the front of the new Dundee.”The festival will feature  acts at Gardyne Theatre, The Reading Rooms, Clarks on Lindsay Street, The Wine Press, The Underworld Cafe – which will be turned into a pop-up underground jazz club – DCA, the VA and several venues in Broughty Ferry.One of the highlights will be an appearance by -year-old American blues legend Otis Taylor, who is playing a UK exclusive gig in Dundee.Agnese said: “It will be a mind-blowing show that you don’t get to see very often.”Local musicians will also be featured in the line-up.Dundee’s own Havana Swing, Gordon McNeil and Malcom MacFarlane will all take to the stage.Another local star who will perform to hundreds of lucky concert-goers is singer, drummer and pianist Ciaran Roberts-Osterberg.The -year-old former Grove Academy teenager, who was diagnosed with autism at a young age, was recently accepted to study at Berklee, the world’s premier music school in Boston, Massachusetts.The grand finale of the festival will be the ever-popular Jazz In The Ferry, which will close the event on Sunday.Ten bands will play over five venues in Broughty Ferry, which is being described as a “festival within a festival”.The VA will feature award-winning vocalist Alison Affleck, who will present her new show in an intimate setting at the Tatha Bar and Kitchen.

title: half of dundee foodbank referrals from homes with kids
story: More than half of foodbank referrals to a Dundee charity are from households with children, shocking new figures reveal.Estimates by Taught by Muhammadshow % of food parcels delivered in the city between August and the start of November were to families with under-s.Rizwan Rafik, project manager at TBM, said the figures were “quite high” but that they aligned with recent figures from the End Child Poverty Coalition which estimated more than a quarter of the city’s children are living in poverty.He said: “Sadly the high number of families being referred is something we see on a daily basis.“The situation doesn’t seem to be improving. People who are in crisis will often think about their children first before themselves.“They won’t want their kids to go without – that’s the last thing they would wish to happen.“It’s so important for schoolchildren to get a balanced diet. For them to do well in education, nutrition goes hand in hand.”The figures also reveal % of households were claiming either because of a delay or a change in benefits, something reported throughout the UK as Universal Credit is rolled out.Almost half of referrals are for just two of the city’s eight council wards – Coldside makes up % of the total, while Lochee has %.The foodbank, as well as TBM’s ious other programmes, is currently on the lookout for additional volunteers.The charity is hosting a volunteer information evening at Sizzlers on Guthrie Street tomorrow from pm, when free food will be provided.

story: BLACK Isle writer Verity Walker, who recently celebrated the publication of her debut novel, Major Tomrsquos War, will do a reading and signing event at Waterstonersquos bookshop in the Eastgate Shopping Centre, Inverness, on Thursday .Written under the name Vee Walker, it is set against the background of World War I and although it is a work of fiction, it is based on real people, places and events drawn from her grandfatherrsquos unpublished war diary.Ms Walker played a key role in the weekends Armistice events in the northern French town of Bavay which he helped to liberate.She delivered lectures at local schools as well as taking part in the Armistice Parade and service at the Bavay war memorial where the Flower of Scotland was sung in her honour along with the French national anthem, La Marseillaise, and God Save The Queen.The Waterstones event starts at pm.Wednesday  Nov  : AM

title: Christmas tree t heading to the Prime Minister
story: A HIGHLAND farmer has won the honour of providing the Christmas tree which will stand outside the Prime Ministerrsquos official residence at  Downing Street.John Junor, of Farr North Christmas Trees, beat off competition from across the UK to win the accolade at what are described as the Oscars of the Christmas tree growersrsquo calendar.Based at Dell Farm, Farr, Mr Junor travelled more than  miles to take part in the annual competition organised by the British Christmas Tree Growers Associationwhich was held this year at Goathurst in Somerset.He received the most votes from fellow growers to become Grower of the Year.He will now supply the ft Christmas tree which will provide festive cheer at the famous London address."I am thrilled to have received the votes of my fellow growers," he said."Itrsquos a true honour and a highlight for us growers."I cannot wait to have the tree delivered to this famous landmark for Christmas."Mr Junor has been a member of the BCTGA for  years but it is the first time he has won the accolade.He also won the competition for Best Fir Nordman and was runner-up for the Best Pine.In the dferent categories, trees will have been nurtured for about eight years to reach competition height of .m ndash the most common height bought by the public.They are judged on their foliage, colour, shape and marketability.Mr Junor has been growing Nordman Fir and Alaskan Pine trees at his farm for more than  years.The farm includes a plantation of , tree and is also home to livestock including cattle and sheep plus many wildle and bird species.In the annual Christmas tree competition,Harry Brightwell, BCTGA secretary, said: "Every year we are delighted with the high standard of entries and the huge effort our growers put in to grow and pick the perfect tree, and create a lovely wreath and this year was no exception."Wednesday  Nov  : AM

title: Dozens of drivers nabbed speeding outside schools
story: MORE than  drivers were caught speeding near schools by police during the October holidays.Enforcement was carried out near a number of schools including Holm Primary, Lochardil Primary, Hilton Primary and Cradlehall Primary.During the week of enforcement  drivers were warned for speeding offences, three drivers were issued with conditional offers of a fixed penalty and  drivers were reported to the procurator fiscal ndash of these, three were reported for dangerous driving offences after vehicles were detected travelling at more than twice the speed limit.A -year-old man who was stopped near Hilton Primary on Thursday will also be reported for a number of other offences, including driving while disqualied and without insurance.Sergeant Gus Murray from Police Scotlandrsquos Highland and Islands road policing team said: ldquoIt is disappointing that drivers continue to fail to comply with speed limits around schools and we will continue to carry out enforcement.It followed similar operations in Inverness in August and September.During school term time reduced speed limits nearby are aimed at improving road safety and encouraging children to walk or cycle.Wednesday  Nov  : AM

title: Highland coach firm pledges to guard jobs after deciding to hand over public service routes
story: DE Coaches has secured Highland Councilrsquos permission to transfer all of its public transport contracts, and almost half of its school transport contracts, to Stagecoach.A council spokeswoman said Stagecoach ldquoagreed to accept them on the existing terms and conditions, and the move will take effect on January .Donald Matheson, founder and managing director of DE, said after the deal has gone through ldquowe will still be a multi- million pound business with over  coaches, a workforce of  people and a clear path forward to fresh growth and progress.He added: ldquoThis arrangement leaves us space to cater for private and contract hire work, which at present we have been turning away.ldquoOur research shows there is considerable opportunity there and wersquoll now have the capacity to meet it which means wersquoll create new jobs further down the line.David Liston, managing director of Stagecoach North Scotland, said assets acquired would include vehicles plus the transfer of council tenders, as well as contracts around Inverness and the Black Isle.He said  staff from DE Coaches would transfer to Stagecoach under TUPE arrangements.He added: ldquoThis acquisition will allow us to further expand our successful bus operations in the north of Scotland where we currently employ around  staff and operate around  vehicles.Inverness South Independent councillor Duncan Macpherson, who has been vocal about his support for a sustainable school bus service in his ward,was pleased to hear the contract transfer terms were acceptable to the council.Cllr Macpherson said: ldquoMy concern is for the provision of the buses for the school pupils and students. I want to know that they can get to school and it is guaranteed. As long as we are covered.A council spokeswoman said the change was not costing the council any more money as it is ldquoon existing terms and conditions.ldquoStagecoach has given assurances about service quality and the council will be confirming details of services with Stagecoach before they are registered with the Traffic Commissioner.ldquoIn some cases there are slight alterations to services but generally they will continue with no change."Wednesday  Nov  : AM

title: New project to offer legal advice
story: PEOPLE in the Highlands are being given a new route to access justice thanks to a partnership between law firm Harper Macleod and the Aberdeen Law Project .The Inverness Law Project , being launched in late November, will see talented law students provide a range of free legal services to iniduals and groups who cannot otherwise obtain legal advice or representation.These services will include holding law clinics, carrying out community outreach and providing legal research resources.The ILP will be student-led, with specialists at Harper Macleod providing support, training and supervision.It is the first spin-off project from the ALP, which since it was set up in .Monthly legal clinics will be held at the Spectrum Centre, covering most aspects of law including housing, employment, consumer issues, charities, discrimination and land disputes.The first clinics are due to be held on November .Chris Kerr, Harper Macleodrsquos lead partner in the Highlands and Islands, said: "We share ALPrsquos passion for access to justice and our involvement in the project is a fantastic opportunity to use our depth of experience and expertise to help give something back to the areas of the local community which need it most."Ryan Whelan, chairman of the ALP board, said: "We have in student director Lauren Frame ndash an exceptionally able and motivated Invernessian ndash and we are looking forward to what Lauren and the team, supported by Harper Macleod, can achieve in Inverness and the wider Highlands over the coming years."Wednesday  Nov  : AM

title: Star fought off nerves for film premiere
story: THERE was a packed cinema waiting for Inverness actress Karen Gillan as she introduced The Partyrsquos Just Beginning, her first feature film as director, writer and star.Most usually seen at premiere events in gowns by top designers like New Yorkrsquos Vera Wang, Karen wore a less formal white T-shirt and black trousers ensemble for the Inverness Film Festivalevent.But the Jumanji and s Of The Galaxy star explained that she and her American producer Mali Elfman had bought their almost identical outfits in Inverness after their luggage was lost flying here from a Moscow film festival.ldquoI was in my pyjamas when I arrived in Inverness! Karen laughed.Her film has already been nominated for Scottish Bafta best film, best debut screenwriter in the Best Independent Film Awards and picked up an artistic achievement award at the Philadelphia Film Festival.The IFF audiencersquos excitement surrounding the screening of the film was matched by Karenrsquos, she revealed.In a short introduction to the film, Karen ndash with Elfman and actress Rachel Jackson ndash said: ldquoThis is the most nervous Irsquove been to show the film because this place is so special to me. Itrsquos where everything started!Karen then explained her transition from actress to screenwriter and film director with her movie.ldquoI wrote it six years ago and knew I wanted to write something based in Inverness. I also knew that the statistics of suicide in young men between  to  in the Highlands was higher than in the rest of Scotland.ldquoI found that a strange and weird contradiction because itrsquos such a beautul place to grow up and it has been voted one of the most idyllic places to live, in Europe ndash in the world. I wanted to explore that through fictional characters.After the film, which features many city locations, such as the cathedral, riverside and Raigmore underpass, IFF director Paul Macdonald-Taylor asked how easy it had been to set the film in Inverness.Karen said: ldquoThere was some pressure ndash not from Mali ndash to film in Glasgow where there is more access to a film crew, but I was adamant I wanted to capture the authentic version of Inverness."Inverness just looks dferent from Glasgow, though we filmed the interiors there. Two Christmases ago we came up and ran around the streets of Inverness filming with a skeleton crew and I was doing my own hair and make-up.The real Inverness features in a few ways in the film ndash Karenrsquos character Lucy has a strong Inverness accent, city actor Matthew Zajac is one of a group of well-known Scottish faces taking cameo roles. People misdialling for a helpline and being put through to the home of Karenrsquos lead character Lucy actually happened to Karenrsquos family in the past, she told the audience.Karenrsquos QA also revealed that on Malirsquos advice the actress had first begun to practise for her role behind the camera by making some short films, one now set to become her next feature film. She is happy juggling her roles in blockbusters with her own films, describing her own as passion projects.Film review at www.whatson-northWednesday  Nov  : AM

title: Young Inverness dancers step things up at prestigious competition
story: Seventeen young dancers from Stepnstyle travelled to the Skegness Freestyle Championships in Lincolnshire, impressing judges with their performances as they ed to the Highlands with an astonishing  medals and trophies.The schools owner and dance teacher Nicky Barclay believes her students success is all down to their hard work and dedication."It was absolutely fantastic," she said."They danced fantastically. We still havent got over how good the results were. The whole weekend was unbelievable."We are so proud of the girls for everything they have done. Some of them have only been competing for about seven months so for them to have so much success at this stage is incredible."Its absolutely mind-blowing."Mrs Barclay says her students get a huge confidence boost from taking part in the competitions ndash and believes they can also be an inspiration to other children."It is such a boost to the girls," she said."They get a lot of support on social media when they are doing well and they get to take all their trophies into school and things like that."They are an inspiration to others too. Other children see what they are doing and decide they want to get involved as well."The girls see other people appreciating how well they are doing and that helps them."Mrs Barclay revealed that the constant support of her pupils parents is crucial to helping the dancers toward success."The parents are so good to us," she added."They are constantly fundraising, and that is so important because it costs a lot to go away to these competitions. Our nearest competition is in Glasgow so we always have to go a long way."Its tough for the girls but when they get the results they are so happy that it makes it all worth it."Wednesday  Nov  : AM

title: caps strengthen mcinnes hand
story: Boss Derek McInnes will use the potential of a Scotland call-up to strengthen signing talks with transfer targets.Four Dons are with the Scotland squad for the UEFA Nations League group ties – Graeme Shinnie, Scott McKenna, Mikey Devlin and Gary Mackay-Steven.McInnes reckons the Dons’ international recognition by national boss Alex McLeish can improve his bargaining position when in talks with potential signings.The winter transfer window opens on January . McInnes will argue that although the Dons may not have the financial clout of some other clubs, performing well at Pittodrie can offer a route to senior caps.With four in McLeish’s squad, Aberdeen are second only to treble-winning Celtic in representation. Five Hoops players are in the squad for the ties against Albania away on Saturday and Israel at Hampden the following Tuesday.McInnes said: “Part of the message when I sign players is to highlight the rewards of signing for Aberdeen. We might not have the financial power of other certain clubs but what we can do is provide a . We have four players involved with the Scotland squad for the Nations League games.“We have had more examples of that in the past, as Peter Pawlett, Ryan Jack, Mark Reynolds and Ryan Christie – as an Aberdeen player – were all involved in Scotland squads in the past as well. The message there when we sign a player is:you perform well for Aberdeen, and we are doing well as a club, then you can become an international player.”Using international recognition with Scotland as a selling point for joining the Dons has been strengthened signicantly under the management of McLeish.Former Scotland boss Gordon Strachan handed one cap to a Dons player during his near-five-year tenure: to McLean, now at Norwich City, in a - friendly defeat of Czech Republic in Prague in March .Under Strachan, who was axed after a failed World Cup  qualying campaign, Reynolds, Pawlettand Jackwere in squads but never capped.Replacement McLeish handed debut caps to McKenna and Shinnie. Centre-back McKenna has six caps, while Shinnie has four. Having been out of the Scotland set-up for five years, McLeish gave Mackay-Steven his second cap in the - friendly loss to Portugal last month.Devlin received a first call-up to the squad for the double header against Portugal and the - Nations League away defeat to Israel. The centre-back has yet to be capped at senior level.McInnes said: “It shows what can be doneyou’re playing well here as you are in the eye of the international manager.“At the moment it’s about getting those representatives into the senior squad, which is something at times we’ve been frustrated with in the past, but it’s great to see that recognition.”Aberdeen also have three players with the Scotland U squad for a friendly with Turkey in Murcia on Saturday: Lewis Ferguson, Bruce Anderson and Connor McLennan.

title: aberdeen bypass talks continue
story: The Scottish Transport Minister is engaged in “frequent regular dialogue” with contractors over the Aberdeen bypass.Talks were held last week between Michael Matheson and contractor Aberdeen Roads Limited in a bid to iron out legal wrangles that are preventing the already-completed Craibstone, Stonehaven and Charleston sections from opening.A further discussion between the parties is due to take place this week to try to get this section of road open, which has been completed for a number of weeks but held up by a contract issue.Contractors have said the scheme will finally be finished in December – later than the previous “late autumn” deadline, which was the third missed deadline on the project.A Transport Scotland spokesman said: “We are engaged in frequent regular dialogue with Aberdeen Roads Limited over the issues the cabinet secretary reported to parliament recently.“Mr Matheson is due to follow up his meeting with an update call early this week.“The cabinet secretary has committed to updating parliament when further information on an opening date is available.”

story: Children who use a fostering service are helped by highly-skilled carers, inspectors said.Monitors from the Care Inspectorate visited Barnardo’s Scotland fostering service on Carden Place, Aberdeen, on September  and have now published their report.The service recruits, assesses and approves foster carers who help children referred by local authorities.They rated the service “very good” for care, support, management and leadership – the second best of six ratings.The report said: “Children and young people were being cared for by highly skilled and well-supported foster carers who were well trained.“The service was highly skilled in connecting with the needs of the children and young people they supported.“Foster carers knew children well.”

title: animal charity in call for north east residents to rehome dogs1
story: An animal welfare charity is calling on the public to rehome dogs currently in its care.The Scottish SPCA is celebrating its annual Staffie Awareness Week from November - and hopes to find forever homes for its dogs.North-east residents are asked to come along to the centre in Drumoak to meet the canines and learn more about them.Animal Rescue and Rehoming Centre manager Graeme Innes said: “We’re always looking to do more to raise awareness of the breed, which is often mischaracterised.“Staffies are one of our most popular dogs and it’s clear to see why – they are friendly, loyal and affectionate dogs.”One of the staffies resident at the Drumoak centre is Naomi. She arrived just over  days ago through no fault of her own.Graeme added: “When Naomi came to us, she was a poor sight. However, as we’ve worked with her and gained her trust she’s transformed into a completely dferent dog.“She’s now a bundle of energy and cuddles.“As much as we love her, we’re desperate to find her the loving family she deserves.”Those interested in rehoming can visit scottishspca.org

title: delays in aberdeen bypass could hold up major city transport improvements1
story: Delays to the opening of the Aberdeen bypass could have a “knock-on impact” on developing major city transport improvements on time.The Scottish Transport Guidancereport aims to give a long-term view of how the £ million Aberdeen city region deal could benefit the region’s transport infrastructure.But a report considered by councillors on the Aberdeen city region deal joint committee said the next stage of work on the appraisal could be held up by the delayed opening of the bypass.Douglas Lumsden, co-leader of Aberdeen City Council, said: “It worries me there’s other projects such as the Haudagain roundabout but also the Stag report which will be delayed by the unknown end date of the AWPR.“We have made sure that the Scottish Government are aware the AWPR will have a knock-on impact on other things we’re trying to do in the city.”A report to members of the committee said the next stage of work will consider the outcomes of the pre-appraisal stage of the Stag report before beginning the full part one appraisal.It said there is a “risk” the AWPR opening schedule will have a “knock-on impact” on timescales, but added this is “not viewed as critical” at this point.It was revealed on Thursday that talks between the transport secretary and bypass contractors were “positive”.Transport minister Michael Matheson met representatives of Aberdeen Roads Limited , a joint venture between Balfour Beatty and Gallord Try, following the admission that repairs on the River Don crossing may take until December to be completed.It was also revealed earlier this week that a £m project to improve the often-gridlocked Haudagain roundabout has been delayed until  after one of two bidders pulled out.A Transport Scotland spokesman said: “We are fully aware of the importance of the AWPR and the benefits it will bring to the north-east. As has been explained at somein Parliament and to the media recently, the contractor has experienced technical issues at the Don Crossing which it is working hard to resolve.“We are working closely with the contractor to deliver this project at the earliest opportunity and they are currently indicating that they will have completed the works at the Don Crossing in December. As a funding partner in the AWPR, Aberdeen City Council is aware of this current situation too.“Works are well under way to prepare the site for the main construction works on the Haudagain roundabout. Progress has not been impacted by the works at the Don Crossing.”

title: golfer paul lawrie to join aberdeens sleep in the park event
story: A golf ace has pledged to join a sleep out to raise cash to end homelessness in the north-east.Aberdonian golfer Paul Lawrie has announced that he will take part in the Sleep in the Park sleep out in Duthie Park in December.The winner of the  Open Championship said that he is not anticipating an easy ride on the night.He said: “I’m not looking forward to it, it’s going to be a dficult night.“But I think it’s a great idea, and it obviously a great charity. vw, px"  “They do some great work, trying to get as many people off the street as they can.“Plus, it’s only one night that they’re asking you to do, so I think it’s fair enough.”Paul had been tipped-off to the existence of the sleep out by a friend, who works with Paul’s charitable foundation.He said: “He’s always been great with the foundation, so he sent me an email explaining what was happening, and askedI would put together a team to take part.”Paul has recruited friends and members of his family, including son and fellow professional golfer Craig and we Marian.He said: “Myself, my we, my oldest son Craig and four of our friends are going to do it.”Paul is currently laid-p with a serious foot injury, having had surgery last month to fix a tendon issue.The golf ace said that his injury would not hamper his ability to take part in the sleep out, as he hopes to have recovered by the time the event takes place.He said: “It shouldn’t have any effect really, I’ll just strap it up, and I’ll be in my sleeping bag with my hot water bottle so I’m sure I’ll be fine.”Cash raised on the night will go towards social enterprise Social Bite.The charity is looking to raise money to fund a nationwide housing project named Housing First.Housing First is an initiative that has been tried and tested across the world, including in Finland and Canada.The project provides housing for people who are sleeping rough, as well as “wrap around” support for any issues that they may have, including mental health or addiction problems.Housing First has eliminated a vast proportion of rough sleeping in Finland, and it is hoped that the same can be done in Scotland.More than  homes have been released for the project in Scotland, with around  of those homes in Aberdeen and Aberdeenshire, with the roll out starting last month across the north-east.

title: its thumbs up for 3am last orders at aberdeen city centre bars
story: Aberdeen City Council has been hailed as “trailblazing” after adopting proposals to allow pubs to stay open until am on Fridays and Saturdays.City centre venues will no longer have to provide “signicant entertainment” to stay open until am on those evenings – a first for a Scottish local authority.The council’s licensing board approved the move as part of its new policy statement yesterday, with convener Marie Boulton claiming it would create a “level playing field” for licensed premises in the city centre.Stephen McGowan, who represents bars and clubs in his role as partner of law firm TLT LLP, said: “You could say by removing the substantial entertainment criteria the Aberdeen board is trailblazing a new approach.“What Aberdeen has done is move away from that and create an opportunity for people to apply for those hours up to am without meeting the criteria.“It is the first board which has taken a more open approach in the way that was meant to be intended by the legislation.”He added that each application would still be decided on its own merits, with police and neighbours able to object, adding later licences won’t be “handed out like confetti”.Nicola Johnston, Aberdeen Inspired’s evening and night-time economy manager, said the decision will give businesses in the city centre the option to “ersy their offering”. She added: “This increase in trading hours allows us to further mature our evening and night-time economy alongside other progressive cities.“It will be an incremental process but one with positive benefits, giving more ied options for the public.”Ms Boulton said the policy provides a  for businesses to be “entrepreneurial”.However, TGC Leisure, which runs venues including nightclub Club Tropicana, has slammed the proposals for safety reasons, claiming there will be more public drunkenness and violence.The firm also said the proposals could lead to the closure of nightclubs in the city and create a situation where there would be a “serious shortage” of trained door stewards.

title: marine jobs potential after shock of north sea oil exploration
story: Keeping old oil and gas s in place could be a “triple win” for the North Sea, creating a fresh wave of employment, according to a conservationist group.The Scottish Wildle Trust said keeping part of the infrastructure could create new marine research jobs “after the shock of oil and gas exploration”, while giving evidence to the Scottish Affairs Committee yesterday.The organisation told the Westminster inquiry into the future of the sector that certain structures have an abundance of marine le around them, and it is not in the best environmental interests to remove them.The taxpayer has a liability of around £ billion for decommissioning oil s, and CEO John Hughes said savings from this could be put in a “marine stewardship fund” for fresh employment.

title: a place for the car as well as the family is crucial for scots when finding a space to call home
story: Modern le is changing what we prioritise when it comes to choosing a place to call home.New research from the Royal Bank of Scotland into Scots’ attitudes to priorities for their home and their hometown shows that a space for their car is as important as the price of a property and the facilities on their doorstep.As our lestyles and priorities change, the way we choose to bank is changing too and that is why Royal Bank is investing in new ways to help make banking easier for customers.From community bankers and mobile branches bringing banks to the heart of hometowns, or new mobile apps and digital banking services allowing customers to bank wherever they are and at any time of day, Royal Bank of Scotland aims to make banking easier and more convenient.For more information on the Royal Bank of Scotland click here. vw, px"

title: bens name next to his spence trophy heroes
story: Ben Read has followed in the footsteps of north-east professionals Richie Ramsay and Greig Hutcheon by winning the Spence Trophy# aged just .Banchory junior Ben lted the title, which is the equivalent to the Champion of Champions tournament for men, by defeating Ally Kinghorn, of Cruden Bay,  in the final at the links course.Ben had earlier defeated Ruaridh Fenwick, of Deeside,  in the semis to book his place in the final.The victory came after some hard work with coach Patrick Walker and Ben is delighted to see his name on the trophy alongside some of the best juniors that the north-east has produced.Ben said: “I feel honoured to have my name alongside someone as successful and talented as Richie Ramsay. It’s an inspiration.”Ben’s father, David, a former Banchory men’s champion, had tried to tempt his son to take up the sport at the age of four but Ben was more interested in football.However, Ben picked up his first set of clubs aged nine and after a season of playing bounce games received his first handicap of  aged  before improving to , then  and eventually seven.Ben’s first major success came this season when winning the Scottish Golf Development Academy’s boys final over the Eden Course at St Andrews courtesy of a three-over-par  accomplished in testing conditions.He followed that up by winning the Banchory junior club championship with rounds of , ,  and  to earn his spot in the Spence Trophy qualying field as his handicap continued to improve to ..Ben got off to a slow start against Ally and lost the first two holes.However, Ben dug deep to fight back and covered the next  holes in one-under-par before winning the match on the th green.He added: “It was a privilege to qualy for and play in such a big event and alongside such a well-mannered young guy in the final.“Ally was an immense opponent and a joy to play against.“I was lucky enough to beat him on the day, as he is an incredible golfer.“I look forward to the chance to play with him again in the future.”Other Banchory winners of the -year trophy include Greig , Norman Hinks , Phil Robband John Murray .Ben hopes to further improve his game with the goal of one day turning professional although he is well aware of how hard that will be.He added: “My hopes are that my passions for golf continue to grow and that I am lucky enough to be able to play this great sport for a living.”
